metadata.case_name: Appellants (purchasers from Ram Swaroop Gupta) v. Ram Agyan Singh and others
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 2370 of 1969 and 583 of 1971

facts.text: Original owner Ram Swaroop Gupta leased the premises to M/s Pioneer Exhibitors and Distributors Limited for exhibiting cinema. Lease terminated by efflux of time on June 30, 1952.

Gupta leased the premises by deed dated October 13, 1952 for 10 years to Ram Agyan Singh, respondent No. 2. No order allotting accommodation to him under S. 7(2) of the Act. Respondent No. 2 used premises for exhibiting cinematograph films.
Disputes arose between parties; Gupta filed suits for recovery of rent and ejectment against respondent No. 2.
Appellants purchased premises from Ram Swaroop Gupta by sale deed dated March 26, 1962.
Appellants filed application under s. 7 of the Act read with rule 6 for release of accommodation in their favour.
Additional District Magistrate allowed application on December 3, 1965, permitting appellants to take possession as premises in illegal occupation of respondent No. 2.
Representation by respondent No. 2 against release order rejected by State Government on January 10, 1966, no provision for interference.
Appellants filed application for eviction of respondent No. 2 under s. 7-A on December 4, 1965.
Additional District Magistrate directed issue of notice under clause 2 of s. 7-A on June 18, 1966, and passed order for eviction.
Revision by respondent No. 2 to Additional Commissioner confirmed eviction order.
Respondent No. 2 filed revision under s. 7-F before State Government; allowed on October 20, 1967, holding respondent No. 2 not liable to eviction.

State Government communicated summary of reasons on January 20, 1968: respondent running cinema under licence from 1952, District Magistrate satisfied lawful occupation, entitled to proviso to s. 7-A(1).
Appellants filed writ petition under Article 226 before Allahabad High Court to quash State Government order and for possession under s. 7-A.
Single Judge quashed State Government order.
Division Bench reversed Single Judge, holding no error in State Government order.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate under Article 133(1)(b).
Appellants filed suit for recovery of possession claiming tenancy expired, without permission under s. 3(1) of Act.
Trial court decreed suit, holding clause 20 of lease deed bars respondent from claiming s. 3 benefit.
High Court reversed, held suit not maintainable without s. 3 permission.
Lease deed clause 20: Parties agree not to claim benefit of Rent Control Act, provisions inapplicable by mutual consent.
Respondent No. 2 in possession from 1953 conducting cinema after obtaining licence from District Magistrate under Cinemas Regulation Act.
Respondent paid rent to Gupta and appellants after purchase.

legal_issues.text: Whether State Government order under s. 7-F allowing revision and holding eviction inexpedient under proviso to s. 7-A(1) suffered from error of law apparent or lack of jurisdiction.
Whether respondent is a 'tenant' under s. 3 of the Act despite no allotment order under s. 7(2), making suit for eviction require permission.
Whether clause 20 of lease deed precludes respondent from claiming protection of s. 3, or is void as against public policy.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government should not have nullified effect of release order under s. 7 by exercising discretion under proviso to s. 7-A against appellants; did not refer to release order or assess hardship to landlords.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 7 and proviso to S. 7-A of U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent not a tenant under s. 3 as lease violated s. 7(2), no allotment order.
Clause 20 of lease deed bars respondent from claiming s. 3 benefit; tenant can waive provision enacted for their benefit, no public policy issue.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Lachoo Mal v. Radhey Shyam; S. 23 Indian Contract Act

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to benefit of proviso to s. 7-A(1) as running cinema under licence from 1952; District Magistrate satisfied lawful occupation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to S. 7-A(1); Cinemas Regulation Act

respondent_arguments.text: Suit not maintainable without permission under s. 3(1); clause 20 illegal and void.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s. 7-A(1) vests wide discretion in District Magistrate/State Government; circumstances like long possession since 1953 with cinema licence relevant, not irrelevant; no error apparent on record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State Government considered relevant factors; release order under s. 7 does not preclude discretion under s. 7-A proviso.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent is tenant under s. 2(g) and s. 3 despite no allotment; lease valid between parties per Udho Dass; pays rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act distinguishes tenants with/without allotment; s. 3 protects both.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 20 void under s. 23 Contract Act as defeats provisions of law; s. 3 based on public policy to protect tenants from eviction without permission, considering scarcity; tenant cannot waive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public policy underlies s. 3 for weaker section; not mere private benefit waivable.

holdings.text: State Government order under s. 7-F valid; no interference justified.
Respondent is tenant under s. 3 requiring permission for eviction suit.
Clause 20 void against public policy; tenant cannot waive s. 3 protection.

precedents_cited.relevance: Lease in violation of s. 7(2) valid between parties, creates landlord-tenant relationship.
Landlord can waive benefit for landlords; but s. 3 for tenants involves public policy, not waivable.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates eviction, release, unauthorised occupation; requires permission for suits against tenants; protects against eviction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition and certificate appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Agreement void if defeats law or against public policy.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed. In C.A. 2370/1969, Division Bench order upheld; State Government revision order valid. In C.A. 583/1971, High Court correct; suit not maintainable without s. 3 permission, clause 20 void.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs in C.A. 2370/1969.

key_quotes.text: The proviso to sub-section (1) of s. 7-A is couched in wide language. A great deal of discretion must, therefore, be vested in the District Magistrate and in the State Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scope of discretion under s. 7-A proviso.

key_quotes.text: We think that s. 3 is based on public policy. As we said, it is intended to protect a weaker section of the community.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds s. 3 non-waivable due to public policy.

key_quotes.text: Everyone has a right to waive and to agree to waive the advantage of a law or rule made solely for the benefit and protection of the individual in his private capacity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes waivable private benefits from public policy protections.
